@Jade_Pickering And to be clear, I think HARKing *is* totally fine when it’s transparent (i.e., when you’re not pretending the study was confirmatory). Data *should* be used to generate new hypotheses if it didn’t confirm your original hypothesis.
@Jade_Pickering (But yeah, I understand some people won’t listen unless there’s a peer-reviewed citation attached. Good luck!)

@Jade_Pickering The logical argument that if they really believe HARKing is totally fine, then it should also be totally fine to have no hypothesis in the intro and accurately describe your hypothesis in the discussion as post hoc.

@bmwiernik I was forbidden from playing with my (male) childhood best friend in the hopes that I would make female friends. Luckily, I found a female best friend who also just wanted to catch frogs in the woods, but she still wasn’t as good cuz she didn’t live close enough to walkie-talkie.

@richarddmorey ^ is because group_by(dat, A, A) is the same as group_by(dat, A)

@richarddmorey This is a little weird but will also work:

tibble(
  A = rep(1:2, 4),
  B = rep(1:2, 2, each = 2),
  C = rnorm(8)
) %>%
  group_by(across(c("A", sample(c("A", "B"), 1)))) %>%
  summarise(C = mean(C))

@richarddmorey grp <- sample(list("A", c("A", "B")), 1)[[1]]

tibble(
  A = rep(1:2, 4),
  B = rep(1:2, 2, each = 2),
  C = rnorm(8)
) %>%
  group_by(across(grp)) %>%
  summarise(C = mean(C))

@vkempe I probably could, but it’s time to get back to the more traditional xmas activities of eating too much and watching films :)

geom_point(aes(x, y, color = I(color), size = I(size)), ornaments) +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_void()

ggplot() +
  geom_rect(aes(xmin = 0, ymin = -1, xmax = 8, ymax = 1), fill = "tan4") +
  geom_col(aes(1:8, 8:1), fill = "darkgreen") +
  geom_col(aes(1:8, -8:-1), fill = "darkgreen") +
  geom_point(aes(9, 0), color = "gold", size = 10, shape = 8, stroke = 3) +

ornaments = data.frame(
  row = rep(1:8, (8:1)*seq(3, 2, length.out = 8))
) %>%
  mutate(x = row + runif(nrow(.), -.5, 0),
         size = runif(nrow(.), 3, 8),
         color = sample(c("red2", "gold", "skyblue1"), nrow(.), T)) %>%
  mutate(y = runif(nrow(.), -9+row, 9-row))

@farid_anvari This is why I like the @PeerCommunityIn model so much. It divorces the decision about whether work is good from the decision about whether a journal has space to publish it.

@farid_anvari This is a result of artificial scarcity of journal space (they can’t accept all good papers) and overwork. Editors don’t have time to work with authors to improve a paper and reviewers drop out before the second round.

One thing you can do to support software citation is to add a CFF file to your public code. If it's on GitHub, they will even give you a template if you create a file called CITATION.cff. https://t.co/nhFcG9wkOn

@mfenner discusses how to use meta-data to make software more searchable and reusable. Points out that software should follow FAIR principles just like data. @npch mentions FAIR4RS https://t.co/Q6pU7RLeJ9

Challenges for software citation:

- a single DOI may reference data, inputs, outputs, and code
- dependencies may not be well documented in meta-data

@JoranJongerling @lakens @andre_quentin @HirstRj I'm thinking about this more from the perspective of a registered reports editor. I might do some simulations to check how different strategies affect the outcome. Of course the parameter estimates from a subsample are more variable, so a conservative estimate is best.

Jake Yeston finds that 12% of Science papers published in 2020 included a citation to code archived at Zenodo. Why might people omit software citations?

- too many references?
- confusing for copyeditors?
- lack of community buy-in?
Zenodo and Zotero can also read the metadata in CITATION.cff files. Learn more about CFF at https://t.co/qsaN4cUzPc
The citation file format (CFF) is a YAML format for providing software citation information. It has been adopted by GitHub, which will automatically detect and display citations from .cff files.

The CRediT contributorship model has a recommended JATS format that the scienceverse R package and shiny app can both create.

https://t.co/INTHfmcjFv

Software citation recommendations in JATS4R:

Only requirements are to identify it as software and include a unique ID like a DOI or URL. Other tags like authors are optional.
Now Melissa Harrison is speaking on https://t.co/zzN1PPY4za. JATS4R develops best practices for tagging research content using the XML standard JATS.
I'm at the #force11 session on software citation. Daniel Katz's slides are chock-full of interesting links https://t.co/Uw6I5J7v56

@lakens @andre_quentin @HirstRj In other words, do I need to adjust alpha at all if I plan to collect whatever N is determined by a power analysis with pre-specified total alpha, power, and effect size, but using simulation parameters that I won’t be able to estimate until I’ve collected M participants?

@lakens @andre_quentin @HirstRj Does it change the adjustment if your first “peek” is *only* used to extract parameters for a power calculation, not to conduct a hypothesis test, and you’d only conduct a test after your required N? (Not what happened here, but if you plan that?)
@lakens @HirstRj Is there a shiny app for calculating the p-value adjustment needed for the single “peek” that allows the power calculation to be done?

@JamesSteeleII @HirstRj @Emily_CBS That’s such a useful pattern! So few people have the right parameters to do a good power analysis (especially for mixed models) until they’ve run an exact pilot, but are reluctant to “waste” subjects on pilot data.

And my mom tells the story of how her father was on strike at GM for months when she was a child. How it demonstrated that those in charge  will never treat workers fairly unless we fight for it. And my conviction to stand in solidarity is renewed. (3/3)

They remind me of all the good that unions have done, and how workers’ rights in the US have decreased as unions got weaker. They have a lot of conservative views I disagree with, but are way more radical than most of my academic colleagues on this topic. (2/3)
Every time we have a strike, I get really anxious about how it affects students. Then I call my parents, who were members of the teachers and auto unions (1/3)  #OneOfUsAllOfUs @UCUGlasgow
